paper_metadata.title: Clinical and genetic profiles of hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis in Taiwan
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper reports six TTR mutations identified in Taiwanese patients with hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis, including detailed penetrance data for the Ala97Ser mutation.

patients.phenotype: Hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis (ATTR) with peripheral neuropathy and variable cardiac involvement

individual_records.evidence_sentence: The Ala97Ser mutation was the most common mutation in this ATTR cohort, accounting for 52 of the 57 ATTR pedigrees (91.2%).
Another two asymptomatic gene carriers with a TTR Ala97Ser mutation were enrolled for the cardiac scintigraphic imaging study.

functional_data.summary: The Ala97Ser mutation is associated with hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis, leading to misfolding of transthyretin and amyloid deposition.

variants.segregation_data: The Ala97Ser mutation segregates with disease in families, as evidenced by haplotype analysis.
variants.population_frequency: Not present in the 125,748 exome and 15,708 whole-genome sequences from unrelated individuals in gnomAD.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on segregation and clinical correlation.
variants.additional_notes: The study suggests a founder effect for the Ala97Ser mutation in the Taiwanese population.
key_quotes: Detailed haplotype analyses demonstrated a shared haplotype in the 47 patients with the Ala97Ser mutation, suggesting a founder effect.
The Ala97Ser mutation was the most common mutation in this ATTR cohort, accounting for 52 of the 57 ATTR pedigrees (91.2%).

patients.phenotype: Hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis with distal paresthesia and cardiac symptoms

individual_records.phenotype_details: Distal paresthesia, chest tightness, diarrhea, erectile dysfunction, and severe axonal polyneuropathy.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The patient with the TTR Glu89Asp mutation presented with distal paresthesia since age 59 years and intermittent chest tightness, diarrhea, and erectile dysfunction since age 64.

functional_data.summary: The Glu89Asp mutation is novel and likely pathogenic, associated with typical phenotypic features of ATTR.

variants.population_frequency: Not present in the 125,748 exome and 15,708 whole-genome sequences from unrelated individuals in gnomAD.
variants.evidence_level: Moderate evidence based on clinical presentation and absence in population databases.
variants.additional_notes: The Glu89Asp mutation is classified as a likely pathogenic variant according to the ACMG guidelines.
key_quotes: The Glu89Asp mutation was novel, and the other five mutations had been reported as pathogenic mutations before.
The patient with the Glu89Asp mutation has a typical phenotype and pathological finding of ATTR, which is highly specific for TTR mutations.

tables_processed.table_caption: Demographic data and clinical features of the 79 ATTR patients
Clinical information of the individuals receiving scintigraphic analysis of cardiac involvement
Phenotype-genotype characterization of individual patients with different TTR mutations

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data was extracted accurately from the provided text.
